ETYMOLOGY: From Latin *filum* ('thread') + suffix *-amentum* (forming nouns). Via Old French *filement*.

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: noun: a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A very fine thread or threadlike structure, especially one forming part of a larger structure or substance.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The scientist observed a delicate filament of protein under the microscope.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 科学家在显微镜下观察到一根纤细的蛋白质丝。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: noun: a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A conducting wire or thread in an incandescent light bulb or electron tube, which is heated to incandescence or to emit electrons.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: (灯泡、电子管中的) 灯丝；发热丝
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The light bulb stopped working because its filament had burned out.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 灯泡不亮了，因为它的灯丝烧断了。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: noun: a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: In botany, the stalk supporting the anther in a stamen.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The anther, which produces pollen, is typically supported by a slender filament.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 产生花粉的花药通常由一根纤细的花丝支撑。
